p: Mobility, people traveling much more frequently and far greater distances than in the past, living in more densely populated areas, centralization of food production and supply and new food vehicles, war, famine and displacement, change in vector distribution and susceptibility, and more opportunities to come into closer contact with wild animals, all represent a potential for emerging infectious diseases, either caused by new or well-known viral agents or by antimicrobial-resistant bacteria to spread rapidly and cause outbreaks locally or globally.
